I am not sure if Oscar Wilde would regard himself as a feminist, but his stage plays certainly provide much that would appeal to advocates of women’s rights. The inferior social position of women in the late nineteenth century, and the imbalanced moral judgements that society imposes on women are recurring themes in Wilde’s plays.We might even say that the women are the stronger characters and the driving forces in all of Wilde’s plays. In Lady Windermere’s Fan and An Ideal Husband, the action is propelled by the female characters, and the male characters act only in reaction to the situation that has been created by the women.The men move the story along in The Importance of Being Earnest, but the women prove to be more than a match for them, and it is clear who calls the shots. Salome tells the story of a frustrated and baulked woman who finds other ways to use the power that society has denied her, rather like Hedda Tesman in Ibsen’s play, Hedda Gabler.In A Woman of No Importance, the action is not led by any of the characters, but it is clear that the main moral issue presented by the play relates to the mistreatment of a woman, and that it is with her that Wilde’s sympathy lies. To Lord Illingworth, Mrs Arbuthnot is a woman of no importance, a former mistress who left him when he refused to marry her so their child could be born in wedlock. It is harder to appreciate the significance of this today, and the modern reader might be irritated by Mrs Arbuthnot’s constant self-abasement and brooding on her sins. However Victorian morality held that sex outside wedlock was wrong, and that the woman who did so was tainted and disgraced, unfit to form part of good society. This creates a dilemma for Mrs Arbuthnot who has concealed her past from everyone, including her son, Gerald. Now Gerald wishes to improve his social status by becoming the secretary of Lord Illingworth, unaware that the aristocrat is his father. To complicate matters Gerald is in love with an American Puritan called (what else?) Hester. Clearly Wilde has heard of The Scarlet Letter. This Puritan is untainted however, and disapproves of women who sin outside of wedlock.To stay quiet about Lord Illingworth’s relation to Gerald is impossible for Mrs Arbuthnot. She cannot stand the thought of him benefitting from, and perhaps being corrupted by, his father. However to reveal the truth is to risk losing Gerald’s regard for her, and to damage his prospects with Hester.A point that Wilde returns to again and again is the contrast between the position of Lord Illingworth and the lower status of Mrs Arbuthnot. He has committed the same sin as her, but he is respected in society and much sought-after, whereas for her an illegitimate child means ruin and censure. When Mrs Arbuthnot finally reveals the truth to her son, his first instinct is to try to force her to marry his father, thereby making their relationship respectable, even though she now despises Illingworth. We see again the absurdity of moral double standards that consider that a woman should choose an option that will make her unhappy simply because it is considered right by society.In the event, the play ends in a typical Wildean fudge. Hester proves to be surprisingly accommodating. Her morals shift overnight, and she helps Mrs Arbuthnot to persuade Gerald not to push marriage on his mother. By the end, the three of them find happiness together, and Mrs Arbuthnot rejects the attentions of Lord Illingworth. It seems that he has now become ‘A man of no importance’.This turnaround to a happy ending may seem unsatisfactory, but it is in line with Wilde’s other comedies. Wilde did not believe in asceticism, sacrifices and pure moral standards. He recognised that life is only supportable when people accept a grey compromise.Nonetheless Hester’s change of heart occurs a little too abruptly, and it is regrettable that nearly two acts of the play amble along without much happening, leaving only limited space for the denouement. However the main story is not one of Wilde’s best, and involves too much hand-wringing and condemnation for my tastes.Wilde himself does not seem especially interested in his story, and so much of the play is a collection of witty aphorisms and bon mots uttered by characters that are only peripheral to the main story. The play contains many of Wilde’s most famous sayings:“Men marry because they are tired; women because they are curious. Both are disappointed.”“It is perfectly monstrous the way people go about, nowadays, saying things against one behind one's back that are absolutely and entirely true.”“The Book of Life begins with a man and a woman in a garden. It ends with Revelations.”“One should never trust a woman who tells one her real age. A woman who would tell one that would tell one anything.”“The English country gentleman galloping after a fox – the unspeakable in full pursuit of the uneatable.”How far one enjoys this play depends more on one’s appreciation of Wilde’s witticisms than it does on following the story. I find Wilde’s sayings mildly amusing, but not as wise or clever as they are often thought to be. However it is still possible to be charmed by Wilde’s elegance and his consummate control of the English language.

this is my third Oscar Wilde play, and i can say they all seem to have the same theme and style, i can't say i found this to be as much a drama, as more similar to the other plays i've encountered, they are full of wit, humour, caricature characters and critical of high society. this one, unfortunately, does not stand out the same way as The Importance of Being Earnest, one of the last things Wilde wrote before he died, in which fact we can also see how his skill matured and transformed with his life, his ideas resonating more clearly and his style shining more bright.funny until the end, the play starts off full of tragicomic remarks, then the major moment is the uncovering of the dramatic situation of the wronged mother to her son, to which the American friend briefly suggest moving to America as the only solution to escape disgrace. the boy's father, who is found in the garden trying to kiss his's sons future wife, will then try to ignore everything and tell the mother she has become too judgemental. some funny quotes:“when good Americans die they go to Paris, when bad Americans die they go to America.” (the contempt of english and french society for America and the popular culture of Paris)"the only form of serious intellect I know is the British intellect”“[I was told that in the garden] there is an orchid as beautiful as the Seven Deadly Sins. - My dear, I hope nothing of the kind, I will certainly speak to the gardener.” “beautiful women are too busy being jealous of other women’s husbands”“So much marriage is certainly not becoming. Twenty years of romance make a woman look like a ruin; but twenty years of marriage make her something like a public building.”“nothing spoils a romance so much as a sense of humour in a woman”“The Book Of Life begins with a man and a woman in a garden - It ends with Revelations.”“[today] all the married men live like bachelors and all the bachelors live like married men”“How can a woman be expected to be happy with a man who insists on treating her as if she were a perfectly rational being? (…) The History of Woman is very different. We have always been picturesque protests against the mere existence of common sense. We saw its dangers from the first. (…) The Ideal Man! Oh, the Ideal Man should talk to us as if we were goddesses, and treat us as if we were children. He should refuse all our serious requests, and gratify every one of our whims. He should encourage us to have caprices, and forbid us to have missions. He should always say much more than he means, and always mean much more than he says. (…) He should never run down other pretty women. That would show he had no taste, or make one suspect that he had too much. (…) If we ask him a question about anything, he should give us an answer all about ourselves. He should invariably praise us for whatever qualities he knows we haven't got. But he should be pitiless, quite pitiless, in reproaching us for the virtues that we have never dreamed of possessing. He should never believe that we know the use of useful things. That would be unforgiveable. But he should shower on us everything we don't want. - As far as I can see, he is to do nothing but pay bills and compliments. - He should persistently compromise us in public, and treat us with absolute respect when we are alone. And yet he should be always ready to have a perfectly terrible scene, whenever we want one, and to become miserable, absolutely miserable, at a moment's notice, and to overwhelm us with just reproaches in less than twenty minutes, and to be positively violent at the end of half an hour, and to leave us for ever at a quarter to eight, when we have to go and dress for dinner. And when, after that, one has seen him for really the last time, and he has refused to take back the little things he has given one, and promised never to communicate with one again, or to write one any foolish letters, he should be perfectly broken−hearted, and telegraph to one all day long, and send one little notes every half−hour by a private hansom, and dine quite alone at the club, so that every one should know how unhappy he was. And after a whole dreadful week, during which one has gone about everywhere with one's husband, just to show how absolutely lonely one was, he may be given a third last parting, in the evening, and then, if his conduct has been quite irreproachable, and one has behaved really badly to him, he should be allowed to admit that he has been entirely in the wrong, and when he has admitted that, it becomes a woman's duty to forgive, and one can do it all over again from the beginning, with variations.”“What is that dreadful girl talking about? - She is painfully natural, is she not?”“The English aristocracy supply us with our curiosities, Lady Caroline. They are sent over to us every summer, regularly, in the steamers, and propose to us the day after they land. As for ruins, we are trying to build up something that will last longer than brick or stone.” (American sense of superiority against the British, attacking even the English cultural heritage through Stonehenge)“examinations are of no value whatsoever. If a man is a gentleman, he knows quite enough, and if he is not a gentleman, whatever he knows is bad for him.”“talk to every woman as if you loved her and to every man as if he bored you”“You should never try to understand them. Women are pictures. Men are problems. If you want to know what a woman really means − which, by the way, is always a dangerous thing to do − look at her, don't listen to her. (…) to the philosopher, my dear Gerald, women represent the triumph of matter over mind − just as men represent the triumph of mind over morals. (…) The history of women is the history of the worst form of tyranny the world has ever known. The tyranny of the weak over the strong. It is the only tyranny that lasts.”the play is definitely entertaining and worth reading/listening to, or even watching, if ever found in a local theatre.

This is a pretty entertaining play with a couple nuggets of truth well worth finding out, and it's filled with sayings that amuse but probably distract from what's at the heart of the play more than they add to it. IMO. But the play is more successful than not, especially if one is inclined to like Wilde, as I am, and would like to see it performed.But it seems like Wilde let loose with the aphorisms that look like they mean something but probably don't. I got tired of that. Lots of "women do this and men do that," including the famous bit about women becoming like their mothers being their tragedy and men not becoming like their fathers being theirs. That's the best one. Among the rest, some draw blood; others are too by-the-numbers to feel like they truly say anything. Probably got laughs, I suppose.It takes a while to figure out who the play is about and what's happening with them. The story of Mrs. Arbuthnot and her adult son, who's being offered an amazing position with Lord Illingworth, emerges from a lot of random dialogue in the first act, where a number of guests at Hunstanton Chase are talking about nothing in particular. Much of it tends toward the behavior of men and women, but all with a jaded, insincere, ironic tone. Lady Hunstanton, explaining why a particular young lady didn't receive an offer of marriage from Lord Illingworth: "But I believe he said her family was too large. Or was it her feet? I forget which." That's funny, and shows how ridiculous marriage had become among the upper classes of England, but it's also pointless conversation. Later: "Poor Lord Belton died three days [after eloping] of joy or gout. I forget which."It's all just fodder for endless, pointless conversations, where the details hardly mattered. That's a critique of the institution, but the reader also begins to feel that nothing means anything; nothing they say is worth attending to. When asked about uneducated people voting, Lord Illingworth says he thinks they are the only people who should. Then he cautions against taking sides, because that "is the beginning of sincerity, and earnestness follows shortly afterwards, and the human being becomes a bore." Later he says that he adores simple pleasures, adding "they are the last refuge of the complex." Maybe that means something. I can imagine something deep there, but I got the feeling that even Wilde was just tossing out jokes, hoping they sounded significant. The whole conversation seems to be just setups for clever bon mots that don't really mean much, and I started to wonder if anything would happen in the story.But we find out that there are secrets and connections and a history between people, and the story does get interesting. It's all about how women get squashed by society for sexual impropriety, but men never have any consequences. It's disappointing that religion and strict morality are taken for granted here, and the prevailing perspective, as a result, is that men should suffer as much as women do, not that women should not. That feels like a missed opportunity, even considering the time of publication. However, you can read the ending as supporting that notion, of treating "sinners" (if you must) charitably, with forgiveness, especially since the least judgmental person in the play is the religious American woman who is often referred to as "the Puritan," and she refuses at the end of the story to hold a woman's past against her.So maybe I should let that perspective get the final word on the topic.For too long, I thought we were supposed to see Illingworth as the lovable cad, like Rupert Everett's Lord Goring in An Ideal Husband. (I haven't read that play yet--it's just the movie for me so far.) Turns out--spoiler--Illingworth's just a cad. His wordplay is self-serving, not self-deprecating, and his apparent immorality is who he actually is. TBH, it all makes a lot more sense when you read the beginning the second time, supplied with backstories and true natures. I wonder if people went multiple times to the play back in the day...My favorite character, in the end, is the earnest and mocked young American woman. I don't know how she would have been received by Wilde's contemporaries, but she's just alright with me. Direct. Sincere. Forgiving. Good stuff.Lots of it is funny, and I like the story. Wilde can absolutely do "clever." Just a bit more heart early on and it would have really worked for me. Still, 4 stars--it comes close.

GERÇEKTEN BİR KADIN ÖNEMSİZ Mİ? Oscar Wilde ile gene buluştuk. Çocukluk döneminde; Mutlu Prens, Bülbül ve Gül, Bencil Dev gibi çocuk hikayelerini okumuştum. Birkaç yıl öncede beraber okuma kitabı olarak “Dorian Gray’in Potresi”ni seçtik, okuduk ve üzerine sohbet ettik. Tek romanı olduğu için onu seçmiştik. Benim okuduğum “Önemsiz Bir Kadın” ise bir tiyatro oyunu. Wilde’ın en tanınmış oyunlarından biri. Wilde gibi bir dâhiyi tek kitapla bırakmak istemediğim için bu kitabını aldım, okudum.  İlk kez 1893 yılında sahnelenen satirik ( yergi türünde) oyun, yüksek tabakayı ve toplumun ikiyüzlülüğünü eleştiriyor. Türkiye’de ilk kez Nurettin Sevin çevirisi ile Milli Eğitim Basımevi tarafından 1948’de yayımlandı. Benim aldığım kitap İş Bankası Kültür Yayınları – Hasan Ali Yücel Klasikler Dizisinden.  Oyunda 15 karakter var ama 6 – 7 karakter öne çıkıyor. Yazar; fakirlik / zenginlik, evlilik / aşk, özgürlük / ahlak gibi karşıt görüşleri, sınıf farkları, kadın – erkek ilişkileri, kadının toplumdaki yeri gibi toplumsal konuları bu karakterlerin ağzından bizlere aktarıyor. Tabii eleştiren bir dille bunu yapıyor.  Sohbette Lady Stutfield: “Aah ah! Dünya erkekler için yaratılmış, kadınlar için değil.” Diyor. Oyunun yazılmasının üzerinden 128 yıl geçmesine rağmen sadece fikren değil uygulamada da bir değişiklik, gelişme yok. Hala cinsiyet ayrımcılığını aşamamış bir toplum olarak medeniyeti nasıl üst seviyeye taşıyacak, gelişeceğiz? Paylaşılamayan nedir? Nihayetinde hepimiz ölümlüyüz. Zaman ve enerjimizi cinsiyet savaşı yerine farklı uğraşılara yönlendirip daha uygar, daha refah yaşamak hakkımız değil mi?  Bir konuşmada Bayan Allonby: “İdeal Koca? Öyle bir şey olamaz. Zaten müessese yanlış.” Diyor. Nasıl teşhis? Hemen kırılmayın beyler, kuralları koyan, şiddet uygulayan sizin cinsiniz. Üstelik atalar ne demiş? “Koca insanı kocatır. İyi bir şey olsa ‘gonca’ derlerdi.”  Sohbet sırasında Lady Hunstanton: “Korkarım İngiltere’de çok fazla yapay sosyal engelimiz var. Alt ve orta sınıflarla gerektiği kadar temas etmiyoruz.” Demiş. O dönemde sadece 3 sınıf var: Asiller, orta sınıf ve alt sınıf. Gün��müzde ise yapılan son araştırmaya göre İngiltere’de 7 sosyal sınıf var: 1- Elitler 2- Prekarya (Prekarite ya da prekarya, 20. yüzyılda tanımlanmış bir çalışan sınıfı. Ağırlıklı olarak; sınırlı-kontratlı, yarı zamanlı, proje bazlı sözleşmeler ile işgücü piyasalarına iş yapan sınıf) 3-Yerleşik Orta Sınıf 4- Teknik Orta Sınıf 5- Yeni Zengin İşçiler 6-Geleneksel İşçi Sınıfı 7-Yükselişteki Servis İşçileri. Sınıf farkları ya da ayrımcılığı hoş değil tabii ki. Ama sosyal sınıf sayısının artması toplumun daha çok bölünmesi demek değil mi? Dikkat uçurumlar derinleşiyor… Lord Illingworth, Gerald ile konuşurken: “ Dünyadaki en muhteşem şeye sahip olduğunu unutma – gençsin! Gençlik gibisi yok. Orta yaşlılar hayata ipoteklidir. Yaşlılar hayatın tavan arasındadır. Ama gençler ‘Hayatın Efendisi’dir. Gençliği bekleyen bir krallık vardır.” Oscar Wilde diğer eseri “Dorian Gray’in Portresi”nde güzelliği öne çıkartmış, önemini vurgulamıştı. Bu oyununda da ‘gençliği’ öne çıkarıp, önemini vurguluyor.  Sohbet ederken Lady Hunstanton: “Ah! Biz kadınlar her şeyi affetmeliyiz, değil mi sevgili Bayan Arbuthnot.” Diye soruyor. Hep alttan alıp, affetmek kadına düşüyor. Kadın olarak kimleri affediyoruz? Baba, kardeş, evlat ve eş… Kan bağı olanların ve yasal bağı olanın affı farklı tabii. Ama fail hangisi olursa olsun, ne kabahat işlerse işlesin her af bir sonra işlenecek kabahat için zemin hazırlamıyor mu? He af yeni bir kabahat için teminat değil mi, emsal teşkil etmiyor mu? Okurken gene yeni şeyler öğrendim, bilgi dağarcığım genişledi. ❌Büyülü Fener: Projeksiyon cihazının ilk haline verilen ad. ❌Peerage: Birleşik Krallık soyluluk kayıtları. İlki 1826’da Londra’da hazırlanmış olan Buke’s Peerage, soy bilim ve arma bilim konusunda rehber haline gelmiştir. ❌Prekarite ya da prekarya, 20. yüzyılda tanımlanmış bir çalışan sınıfı. Ağırlıklı olarak; sınırlı-kontratlı, yarı zamanlı, proje bazlı sözleşmeler ile işgücü piyasalarına iş yapan sınıf.

Поціновувачам Уайльда, а особливо головного його твору — Портрета Доріана Грея, а особливо самого яскравого і неоднозначного його героя — до неможливого цинічного лорда Генрі, що сипле афоризмами і легко може майже кожному довести, що чорне — то біле, цей твір теж має сподобатися. Так як на сторінках цієї п'єси фактично присутній той же герой, правда з іншим ім'ям, але в тому ж амплуа - це лорд Іллінгворт. І він не просто сипле своїми фразами, що так сподобалися багатьом любителям Портрета, і що плутають чорне з білим, добре зі злим, а за одне й людей, що його слухають, але в п'єсу увійшли фактично повтори окремих фраз, хоч і з косметичними змінами. Ну, наприклад, фраза: «Для того, щоб повернути свою молодість, я готовий робити все — тільки не вставати рано, не займатися гімнастикою і не бути корисним членом суспільства».Звичайно, є й нові істини імені лорда Генрі-Іллінґворта: «Добре зав'язана краватка — це перший важливий крок у житті» — мені чомусь здається, що ця теза, не просто гарний вислів покликаний шокувати публіку, але справді виражає суть автора, можливо за цим лордом-спокусником і ховається внутрішнє "Я" автора? Тому автор уже заочно мені не милий, а будь ми знайомі в реальності — дуже сумніваюся, що змогли б зійтись характерами. Не мій це автор, скільки б ним не захоплювалися, порожній і шкідливий (особливо яскраво видно на його дитячих казках). Хоча наскільки б деякі визначні люди не були б злими й огидними — вони завжди мають натовпи шанувальників. Так і головний денді і гульвіса автора - Доріан Грей - кружляв голови і захоплював за собою молодих людей і дівчат, спокушав їх прикладом свого безтурботного, гріховного, але зовні такого блискучого світського життя, а потім без жалю кидав у бруді і мчав далі за новими жертвами, що не переставали ним захоплюватися, як метелики невтомно гинучи на полум'ї яскравої, але згубної свічки. - Отже так, для Доріана першим кроком краватка, але аж ніяк не занапащені ним душі.Якщо ж хтось під враженням фраз лорда і не поділяє думки про їхню згубність, все ж таки знаходить їх повними вишуканого розуму «не для всіх», то ось ще одна фраза, яка яскраво ілюструє всю їхню підсумкову порожність і нульову цінність, ця фраза дозволяє дати загальне уявлення про якість майже всієї балаканини лорда, що тут, що в Портреті, причому вислів обраний просто на вскидку і я не ставив за мету вибрати саме найяскравішу своєю порожнечею фразу: «Будь-яка думка аморальна. Її суть у руйнуванні. Коли ви думаєте про щось, ви це губите. Нічого не може перенести впливу думки». І як? А що ж це все ж таки має означати то? Чи це ще перекладач доносив свою лепту?Але є й різниця між цими двома творами. Якщо в Портреті багато читачів не могли однозначно визначити позитивний це герой чи негативний, то в «Жінці, не вартій уваги», він точно негативний. Хоча, написавши останню фразу, я чомусь перестав у ній бути так впевнений, і дивлячись на масу позитивних і захоплених відгуків по Доріану, починаю думати, що і тут можуть знайтися читачі, які зможуть визначити героя, що спокусив обіцянкою одруження молоду нерозумну дівчину, одурив її і незабаром кинув зганьблену з дитиною на руках, що жодного разу не поцікавився потім долею цієї жінки і свого сина, як позитивного, оскільки йому все виходить дуже яскраво і цинічно пояснити!А так, якщо спочатку цей твір — пустопорожня балаканина на черговому рауті, то в кінці — не "найбагатша" мелодрама. (Може автора впору зараховувати до одного з родоначальників мелодрам? 😉). Але, д��кілька сцен вийшли досить цікавими, розташування героїв за традиційністю шкали цінностей однозначніша за Портрет, так що і оцінку я навіть поставлю на бал вище. 7/10

Wilde has not disappointed me once! He lives up to his hype. Is one of the most quotable plays I have ever read?? Probably! Quotations/dialogues that are 'fresh' and impactful; a welcome break from the platitudinous statements that we are bombarded with on social media these days!Lots of people have adorned their reviews with quotes and I myself noted many down. How darn right clever Wilde was!!!!His writing is playful and unpredictable. There are humorous lines but I wouldn't call this a comedy. I know many plays where comedy has been written in as specific characters or scenarios aside from the main plot and this shows variety and adeptness. All the writing Greats had this quality. Whether for shock value or not, it was thrilling to read the culturally non-formulaic/unobvious views of certain characters especially the arrogant Mrs Allonby in her after-dinner revelations to her all-female company.One such is example is when she revealed to them the following:'When Ernest and I were engaged, he swore to me positively on his knees that he had never loved any one before in the whole course of his life. Unfortunately however I made no inquiries of any kind till after I had been married four or five months. I found out then that what he had told me was perfectly true. And that sort of thing makes a man so absolutely uninteresting'Then...'I don't think the frivolity of the wife has anything to do with it. More marriages are ruined nowadays by the common sense of the husband than by anything else. How can a woman be expected to be happy with a man who insists on treating her as if she was a perfectly rational being?'And.... ' The ideal husband? There couldnt be such a thing. The institution is wrong'Published in 1894 I find it useful to put myself in the time and understand the climate - socially, politically etc to get the most out of the writing but this play is full of surprises. His characters make many insane characters of his counterparts' plays look like they were the sanest of people. And yet there is a moral plot. Even for that period, late 19th century, the ending sequence is still relevant today. A justice had been served and 'right' was done despite what the climate at that time had generally prescribed in terms of children out of wedlock etc. Wilde was well ahead of his time. Noone needs me to tell them that.Now for my favourite quotes!1. Hester: I dislike London dinner partiesMrs A: I adore them. The clever people never listen and the stupid people never talk.Hester: I think the stupid people talk a great deal.Mrs A: Ah, I never listen!2.Lord Illingworth: The soul is born old but grows young. That is the comedy of life.Mrs A: And the body is born young and grows old. That is life's tragedy.3.Lord Illingworth: Discontent is the first step in the progress of a man or a nation.4.Lord Illingworth: People nowadays are so absolutely superficial that they don't understand the philosophy of the superficial.5.Lord Illingworth: All thought is immoral. Its very essence is destruction. If you think of anything, you kill it. Nothing survives being thought of.

Esta obra de teatro de Oscar Wilde, estrenada en 1893, no es su mejor trabajo, sin embargo fiel a su costumbre el escritor plasma en ella una fuerte crítica a la clase alta, a la cual pertenecía pero despreciaba por encontrarla superficial y vana. De hecho, esta crítica se hace presente en la primera parte de la historia la cual trascurre en la casa de campo de Lady Hunstanton, en la que podemos apreciar como sus amigos ricos a los que ha invitado a una fiesta de jardín (además de mostrarse demasiado ociosos) invierten su tiempo en chimes de mal gusto incluso a través de personajes como Lady Coraline, Wilde, refleja la hipocresía y la doble moral de la sociedad de su tiempo. La historia es muy breve, tanto que sólo cuenta con dos escenarios. Los personajes pese a estar estereotipados cuentan con diálogos muy inteligentes, sobresalientes y por supuesto llenos de ingenio. Además, la crítica del escritor trasciende, ya que no sólo se enfoca en el comportamiento de la clase alta pues plantea problemas sociales, culturales, de género, económicos y por supuesto políticos, esto a través de Lord Illingworth, personaje que por su carga ideológica (además de su fino sarcasmo) podría atreverme a decir es el alter ego del escritor en Una Mujer Sin Importancia. El melodrama de Wilde pese a ser simple, en estructura, y caer de repente en la exageración, no choca por la época en la que fue concebida. Hay que entender que Wilde vivió en la época victoriana, cuando las mujeres tenían muy pocos derechos en comparación con los hombres, lo cual destaca en la segunda parte de la obra. Otro acierto dentro de la historia es, que pese a caerse de pronto, logra salir a flote para después mantener su ritmo gracias al trasfondo filosófico con el que cuenta y a un secreto que es develado en un momento cumbre. ******Citas destacadas. " ¡Ah! El Mundo está hecho para los hombres, no para las mujeres". " ¡No diga eso! Nosotras estamos mucho mejor que ellos. Hay más cosas prohibidas para nosotras"."Es enormemente monstruosa la costumbre que tiene la gente hoy en día de decir cosas contra los demás a espaldas suyas, que son absoluta y enteramente ciertas". "Excluyes a tu sociedad de lo amable y lo bueno. Te ríes de lo simple y puro.viviendo, como todos ustedes, en otro y por ellos, necesitan sacrificarse, y si les arrojas pan a los pobres, es meramente para mantenerlos callados por un tiempo ". "Amas la belleza que puedes ver y tocar, la belleza que puedes destruir, pero de la belleza invisible de la vida, de la belleza intangible de una vida superior, no sabes nada "."La felicidad de un hombre casado depende de las personas con las que no se ha casado". Oscar Wild's writing is pure wit and intelligence. He makes you laugh, he makes you think. He was a man so aware of how ludicrous upper-class society was and his mockery of its people is clear in his every satirical work. He isn't afraid to point out how superficial and idiotic the women are and has no qualms pointing out how arrogant and egotistical the men are.He has a very clever way of exposing high society life as being little more than low society in fancier clothes and big draughty halls.A Woman of No Importance isn't as light and comical as, say, The Importance of Being Ernest, though it has its moments, instead, it presents a harsher aspect of society, exhibiting how unjustly women were treated. If a man did wrong is was accepted simply as the usual and even fanciful behaviour of a man; a sort of 'boys will be boys' understanding. But if a woman does wrong she is condemned, disgraced and cast of from society life, forcing her to either accept her dishonourable fate or live a lie. This play highlights perfectly the condemnation of woman against woman, more so even than men. I almost got the sense that a man wouldn't particularly care about a woman's past or her lost virtues, but it is the women who are quick to judge whilst being uninformed on the matter altogether.I was very pleased with Mrs Arbuthnot's decision at the end regarding Lord Illingworth. After what he did and how callous he was with her feelings, he didn't deserve a moment of her time. It was great to see a woman from a play of Victorian times stand up for herself and tell the obnoxious man where to stick it. I was a little worried the play would end in romance (undeserved on Illingworth's part) but thankfully Wilde didn't write Mrs Arbuthnot as an insipid female ready to throw herself into the arms of a former lover, ignoring his past misdemeanours. A very satisfying ending indeed.The tension and drama in this play were delicious and the writing, of course, was masterful. I don't expect anything less from Wilde. I could see the comedic moments on a stage with Lady Caroline passing from room to room always looking for Sir John, and I imagine it would be very funny.I'd really like to see this performed live sometime as the wit of Oscar Wilde is truly something that needs to be experienced firsthand. The standout quotes to me were,"When a man is old enough to do wrong he should be old enough to do right also.""Duty is what one expects from others, it is not what one does oneself.""The only difference between the saint and the sinner is that every saint has a past and every sinner has a future."

This play is somewhat more moralizing and biting that some of Wilde's works, in my opinion as is deals ably with the conventions and social mores of the time and their inherent hypocrisies. Of course, this is true of all his work but seems particularly the case here. That is not to say that the famous and wonderful whimsy and witty wordplays are not to the fore as well as they certainly are. However in "The Importance of being Earnest" the rogues in the play are likeable and their witticisms therefore seem more congruous than they do here, in the mouth of Lord Illingworth. This character is shameless and, although funny as most of Wilde's characters are, has few redeeming features and leaves at the curtain basically the same nasty character. This is actually refreshing as there is no happy ending here, but again, the whole seems a little discordant. That may be the point and one that I have missed. I love the writings of Oscar Wilde. The more one reads him the more one finds some of his witticisms to be written long similar lines, but they are laugh out loud funny and to quote the extremely pithy Monty Python sketch makes one think: "I wish I had said that". When you overlay this on top of his social satire and commentary, you have a genius indeed. I know he is widely admired but probably never enough in his later life. This is perhaps not a masterpiece but is a great play - reading it makes me desirous of a trip to see this performed live again where it, of course, really comes to life.

Gerald is a young man who secures an appointment as secretary to the rich and flirtatious ambassador, Lord Illingworth. His mother objects to the moral character of his new employer, but can give no concrete reason without revealing her dark past. Gerald is determined to accept the post, because he is in love with a young American lady and needs the money to get married. Throughout the play, various rich and titled characters gossip about London high society, and flirt with each other, and say a lot of shameless nonsense.One of the main reasons why I love Oscar Wilde's hilarious plays is the silly dialogue. The characters say such idiotic things, and it always makes me laugh. Almost the entire first act is fluff and character introductions, but it is such entertaining fluff that I didn't mind. Of course, the social commentary is an undercurrent that lies under every scene, exposing the rich elite as vapid, immoral, and selfish.I really enjoyed the plot in this one, and the conflict that Gerald and his mother experience keeps the story moving forward. The last act gets more serious, and the drama is quite passionate.I was intrigued by the main characters, and appreciated the gradual unveiling of their personalities. I was imagining their dialogue in my head as I read it, wondering how they would say the lines, and what their expression and body language would be. They are extremely vivid and lively even on paper!

I bought a collection of Wilde's plays after enjoying "The Importance of Being Earnest" so much. Since then, I have read some of his more prominent works, and he has never failed to make me chuckle and haw at random moments in reading.So imagine my surprise at tearing up at the end of this one. Where others of his plays end as light and fluffy as they began, with simple and positive messages such as forgiveness or enjoying life on a shallower scale, this story felt very emotional in contrast. The monologues on dealing with shame make me wonder if they came from Wilde's own heart, and don't fall far from the exact same issues we deal with today. I don't know much about Wilde's personal story besides his jail time for homosexuality, but I do wonder if the burden of living with his societal and religious shame came through in this play. Additionally, the optimistic, idealistic, and often misguided American character serves as hope here. She offers the chance at freedom, of change, of possibility, in comparison to the stagnant structures of English society. I really enjoyed this. My only dislikes, such as not knowing the characters for 3/4 of the play, are probably due to the injustice of reading and not watching it, which I hope to do anyway sometime this week.I'll make sure to bring tissues with me~

"the world is made for men, not for women”.Not as funny as his other plays, and not as well written, with more than a touch of the sentimental; still I don't mind that too much, nor do I mind the slow first act which just lingers on a bit too long, because it does something none of Wilde's other plays do: it shows the darker side of the whole dandy lifestyle. Wilde's dandy's can easily utter things like: “To win back my youth, there is nothing I wouldn't do - except take exercise, get up early, or be a useful member of the community.”or:“My dear young lady, there was a great deal of truth; I dare say, in what you said, and you looked very pretty while you said it, which is much more important.” Without any consequences whatsoever. But in this play, there are consequences, and the burdens fall plainly on the women, who have to suffer when the men go of scot-free. It is a quite feminist, harsh satire of Victorian England. It pierces all the ingenuity, dishonesty and casual, albeit funny, sexism, and even if it does so with more than a touch of the dramatic and old-fashioned, it is still quite refreshing to hear a 19th century character tell a high and mighty lord that she does not find his marriage proposal as generous as he thinks it is, but would rather say alone.

Wow. This play packs an emotional punch. While the plot does not really pick up until near the end of the second act (although if you enjoy Wilde’s witticism and social commentary like I do, you’ll still thoroughly enjoy the first act), once it starts, it is phenomenal. Wilde’s criticism of society’s double standard for men and women, especially in regards to extramarital sex (although he manages to touch on a wide variety of topics dealing with women during this time period), is absolutely amazing. I especially enjoyed Act 4. The mother’s character is just so raw and tormented, it’s impossible not to ache for her (I thought her story was very similar to Fantine’s from Les Miserables, both in plot and emotional impact). And Lord Illingworth is so horribly despicable—very similar to Lord Henry from The Picture of Dorian Gray—I hated him completely. I definitely enjoyed this play as much as The Importance of Being Earnest. While it had none of that play’s side-splitting hilarity, it was much more impactful. Whether or not you’re a Wilde fan, I would definitely recommend this play. (Side note: Many of the themes reminded me of Henrik Ibsen’s “A Doll’s House.” They share many similarities in how they address the topic of unfair treatment towards women.)

مسرحية تتحدث عن تعيين اللورد إلينجوورث لجيرالد سكرتيرا له رغم ان هذا الشاب ليس له اية مؤهلات تدعو اللورد ان يوظفه. جيرالد ابن وحيد لامه لا يعرف شيئا عن ابيه. وجد هذه الوظيفة فرصة لتحسين مستواه. لكنه عليه ان يقنع امه بذلك. الكل يثني على اللورد ويشيد به . لكن الام ترفض ان يشتغل ابنها لدى هذا اللورد وحاولت ان لا توضح له الاسباب لكن تحت اصراره تبوح لها ان هذا اللورد هو ابيه وانه غرر بها وحنث بوعده بالزواج بها وحينما انتقلت له الثروة تنكر لها وانه شخص لا يؤتمن. في حفلة يحاول اللورد تقبيل فتاة فترفض وتحدث مشكلة وينقذ جيرالد الفتاة من الورد. يطالب جيرالد امه بان تتزوج من اللورد لتسترجع كرامتها وما تعاني من نبذ المجتمع لها لأجلها وليس لاجله وكل هذا بحضور الفتاة التي انقذها. ترفض الام ذلك وتخبره انها من اجله تحملت كل شيء وانها مستعدة لاجله ان تتحمل اكثر لكن لن تتزوج من ابيه لان ذلك اكثر الما وضررا لنفسها وتنضم الفتاة لراي الام. يخرج الابن والفتاة الى الحديقة الخلفية ويحضر اللورد الى بيتهم ويطالب الام بحقه بولده ويعدها بانه سيتهم بمستقبله ويورثه الكثيرترفض الام ذلك وتخبره ان ابنه يحتقره وانه سيتزوج من تلك الفتاة اللتي حاول ان يقبلها بالغصب وانه عليه ان ينساه فلا وجود له في حياة ابنه. فيخرج ويدخل الشابان من الحديقة ويسأل امه ان كان هناك احد قبل ان يدخلا فتخبره امه انه كان رجلا بلا أهمية.تبدأ المسرحية بعنوان امراة بلا اهمية لتنتهي برجل بلا اهمية.

Wilde's witticisms and constant satirical dialogue was the most enjoyable part of the book, (as well as the ending of course!). I wished that Hester was a more nuanced and complex character as she had such strong opinions and was quite confident yet in the book she was kind of written off as a bit of a damsel in distress. I guess that might be because of the time this play was made, and my much more modern views on politics and gender. She is the reason for the good ending though and she was a good character, overall. I found myself hating almost every other character due to their absurd outlooks on life and society but I guess that comes down to Wilde's ability to write realistic and silly characters really well. In my opinion, I found the main and most important characters (Hestor, Mrs. Arbuthnot, Gerald, Mr. Illingworth... especially Illingworth) to be kind of pathetic in parts. This took away a bit of likeability from Hestor, Mrs. Arbuthnot and Gerald but not too much so that I disliked them.Some of the dialogue is long-winded and sometimes the plot frustrates me but was a pretty good read in the end."Hallo, mother, whose glove is this? You have had a visitor, who was it?""Oh! no one. No one in particular. A man of no importance".

The title "A Man of No Importance" would capture the essence of this story, as it is said by Mrs Arbuthnot in the end. I couldn't agree more.It is always wonderful to read Oscar Wilde's works, stands true to the thoughts and conversation we have in this century. I guess nothing really changed.The pep talk from Lord Illingworth to Gerald draws parallel to the chat between Henry Wotton and Dorian Gray. I found their conversations quite similar when they talked of youth in particular. The other characters found Lord Illingworth to be of an immoral nature, he knew how to talk, influence people and he said that a man who can rule over London's dinner table can rule the word. The same can be described about Lord Henry Wotton.The one character that amused me so much, was the wife of Dr. Daubeny. She was not physically present, but is a topic of conversation between the Doctor and Mrs Hunstanton. The excuses he gives of his wife's ill health, which leaves her incapable of attending social gatherings makes me suspicious. She could be someone who doesn't prefer crowd, or despises Mrs Hunstanton in particular. We will never know.

Just brilliant. I love Wilde's description of men and women and their relationships. He gets it spot on every time. I would go on but fear I may get emotional.One should never trust a woman who tells one her real age. A woman who would tell one that would tell one anything.Men always want to be a woman's first love. That is their clumsy vanity. We women have a more subtle instinct about things. What we want is to be a man's last romance.He should never run down other pretty women. That would show he has no taste, or make one suspect that he has too much.Men marry because they are tired; women because they are curious. Both are disappointed.When good Americans die they go to Paris....And when bad Americans die, ...they go to America.We have the largest country in the world, Lady Caroline. They used to tell us at school that some of our states are as big as France and England put together.Ah! you must find it very draughty, I should fancy.What do you think she'd do if I kissed her?Either marry you, or strike you across the face with her glove. What would you do if she struck you across the face with her glove?Fall in love with her, probably.

This is very witty, and as with the other plays I've read by Wilde, I recognise a number of lines. He's certainly a very quotable writer! I can't help but think that more attention has been given to the prose than to the story, however - and it does seem a bit lumpen, that story. Perhaps it's because the romance in it is only a secondary thing, between two secondary characters? For the most part it's a straight drama that centres on the confrontation of Lord Illingham with the woman who, twenty years ago, he'd seduced and abandoned. Much of the play is concerned with the differing standards that men and women are held to under such circumstances: she is ruined, while he is allowed back into decent society, even if he is the more at fault. I'm completely with Wilde on this, and I suspect with a very good actress Mrs. Arbuthnot would be enormously affecting - she's affecting even when only reading the play - but I read Lady Windermere's Fan a couple of days ago, also by Wilde, and when it comes to portraits of so-called fallen women, Mrs. Erlynne leaves Mrs. Arbuthnot for dead.

“It is perfectly monstrous,' he said, at last, 'the way people go about nowadays saying things against one behind one's back that are absolutely and entirely true.”Once again another witty, hilarious and feminist masterpiece by Wilde. I am so very, very glad to have read this play (pun intended). The character dynamics, relationships and interactions were executed perfectly and I loved the subliminal girl-power messaging as it's so ahead of its time. It was so amusing how Lady Caroline treats Sir John as her personal servant 🤣 And I'm seriously shipping Lord Illingworth and Mrs Allonby, their convos were just on point and filled with intellectual banter. These 2 convos were my faves:“LORD ILLINGWORTH What do you think she'd do if I kissed her?MRS ALLONBY Either marry you, or strike you across the face with her glove. What would you do if she struck you across the face with her glove?LORD ILLINGWORTH Fall in love with her, probably.”“MRS ALLONBY You have your looking-glass.LORD ILLINGWORTH It is unkind. I merely shows me my wrinkles.MRS ALLONBY Mine is better behaved. It never tells me the truth.LORD ILLINGWORTH Then it is in love with you.”

Read this for a class project, and maybe it would have worked better had I seen a performance, but I didn't enjoy it as much as the others. It could also be because I've read so many Wilde plays in a row, who's to say! There's a lot of what feels like padding in this book, especially in terms of Illingworth's many senseless dialogues, though some were hilarious and witty, making points about the senselessness of European society during this period and politics. There were a number of scenes I appreciated, including the very end, Hester's speech, but the book lagged on lengthy dialogue that went nowhere. The dialogue between Illingworth and Gerald's mother was especially strong, with her accusations. On the other hand, the first scene by the tree felt especially pointless, setting up the decadent lifestyle of these rich people and their attitudes towards marriage but not even mentioning the scandal that comes out in scene two. There are also a few too many characters, some of which play very small roles. Overall, this has some great witticisms, but I don't think I'd have read it if not for this project, though the last scene almost made it all worth it.

Reading a play after so many novels was a great change! Sometimes when I was reading the last few books, I was feeling bogged down with the details in between conversations so a play - with only dialogue - was exactly what I needed. Sometimes old fashioned humor is no longer found funny today, and maybe this isn't as funny now as it was back then, but I still liked the jokes. I could see how it would be amusing to see on stage. I think Wilde is clever, with his choice of words and the course of action. I really didn't know what he would do with the ending and I could see it turning in completely opposite ways and working out well. I really enjoy reading old fashioned works that focus on society because of how much these things have changed; I find society such a crazy thing back then! This play has an American visitor at the English country dinner party and several women have great speeches about what they want in relationships and in a man, all ridiculous notions and humorous ideas. I was really entertained. :)

تثير اهتمامي كتابات أوسكار وايلد، لأنها تعكس طريقة تفكيره المختلفة عن مجتمعه في ذلك الزمان، فاخترت مسرحية امرأة بلا أهمية بناء على تراتبية عشوائية كنت قد وضعتها من قبل، ولم أكن أعتقد أنني سوف أُسعد بمحتوى هذه المسرحية وسوف تلمسني الحورات التي قيلت على لسان الشخصيات.تدور أحداث المسرحية في العصر الفيكتوري في إنجلترا، ضمن عائلة ارستقراطية تستضيف زائرة من أميركا، ونفهم من الحوارات التي تجري بين الشخصيات الفرق بين المجتمع الإنجليزي والمجتمع الأمريكي، ورأي الرجال بالنساء ورأي النساء بالرجال، والتهميش الذي كانت تعيش فيه المرأة آنذاك.من الأمور التي تثير السخرية والإحباط أنك -كعربي- حين تقرا الحوارات فلن تشعر بالغربة كثيرا أو بالفارق الزمني بيننا وبين شخصيات الرواية، فما أشبه مشاكلهم واهتماماتهم باهتمامات العالم العربي في الزمن الحالي، فنحن قطعا شعوب متأخرة عن ركب التحضر الإجتماعي.الفكرة العامة للمسرحية رائعة، والتسلسل في الأحداث كان مناسبا، قد تشعر ببعض الضياع في بعض الحوارات، لكن ذلك لن يؤثر على فهمك للأحداث، الحبكة قوية نوعا ما رغم افتقار كشف بعض الأحداث للإثارة، لكن ربما ذلك يعود لأمر متعلق بطريقة عرض المسرحيات لا أكثر، النهاية مرضية وربما سوف تجعلك تبتسم .

This book felt like it was written in two separate times. The first two acts first and then, months later, the last two acts (I just looked it up, this may have actually been the case! I feel smart). The first two acts are the dullest I have read from Wilde. There were too many characters and, even though they had slightly different and distinguishable characteristics, it wasn't enough for me so as to not go back to the character sheet and remember who they were. The conversations were vapid (and I understand that it was on purpose), but did they really need to extend over two acts and let the great majority of the conflict happen and be resolved in the last acts? It certainly didn't help that there was a huge gap between me reading the first and last two acts, but I feel that this came about from me losing interest because of this very reason. The drama REALLY escalated after (I loved it though) and then the final act came in with unexpected compassion from what I would have expected from a play in 1893.TL;DR: Loved the ending, hated everything else.

This is a more serious play compared to "The Importance of Being Earnest" with a more dramatic conflict. The play still has Wilde's colorful commentary on English society through his witty dialogue, but with a dark secret at the root of the conflict. There is also an examination of the different moral values between men, women, and Americans compared to the British. We are introduced to an American woman, Hester Worsley, visiting England who does not understand the values of the British upper class and they do not understand her. The play also examines marriage and why some people marry. Is it for the right or the wrong reasons? The other two main protagonists in the play were sympathetic and I felt such strong hatred for the male character who you could say is antagonist. The play is short like "The Importance of Being Earnest", though it has one more Act than that one did and as I said, this play has a bit more drama.

‘Women are hard on each other’‘Who being loved is poor?’‘I don’t think that we should ever be spoken as other people’s property’. Even though at this point, I’m pretty aware that classics are as relevant as ever, I’m still always surprised when I find their relatability. You start reading this play by reading it out in your awful British accent and end up not putting it down till you’ve read the last act and the last impactful line. The interactions between the women, the staunch differences in the characteristics of Mrs Allonby and Hester, it all ties in so well with the conversations I still have with my friends. The guilt and shame felt by Mrs. Arbuthnot and the almost frat boyish character of Lord Illingworth still holds true with so many contemporary relationships you see today. This has drama, humour and a very, very clear understanding of the shame that women have to go through and the infamy that men gain from it.

I believe I mentioned in my review of "The Picture of Dorian Gray" that it had a great last line. It seems that this was a specialty of Oscar Wilde, as many of his plays wrap up with a very satisfying bon mot. Often it even incorporates the title of the play. Of all of these ending lines, though, I would rate the one for "A Woman of No Importance" as the best. It perfectly encapsulates the theme and message of the play.With the exception of "Salome," which stands alone in its style and setting, all of the work I've read by Oscar Wilde takes place among the English upper class. The action mostly takes place in drawing rooms of country estates and the like. "A Woman of No Importance" was interesting in that it has an American character who offers a strong contrast with the society around her. There were also some quite funny scenes, more reminiscent of "The Importance of Being Earnest" than "Lady Windermere's Fan." But overall the tone of the play was fairly serious. The main impetus of the drama is a man who had seduced a young woman of lower status, only to abandon her (the "woman of no importance" of the title) when she was pregnant. Now, unbeknownst to him, he has agreed to take on their son as his personal secretary. The play presents the woman and her plight most sympathetically, which may have seemed radical for the late nineteenth century. But it had an air of sentimentality that made the play seem more dated to me. Nonetheless I think anyone who has enjoyed Wilde's other work will enjoy this play.
